title-group.article-title: Exergy-based analysis of conventional coal-fired power plant retrofitted with oxy-fuel and post-combustion CO2 capture systems

abstract.p: Capturing and sequestering CO2 from coal-fired power plant is being proposed as one of the key solutions for stabilizing greenhouse gas concentration in the atmosphere. Recently, absorbing system and oxy-fuel combustion technology have been proposed as attractive options for capturing CO2 in power generation systems utilizing hydrocarbon fuels. This study is focused on energy and exergy analysis to compare the oxy-fuel combustion and absorbing system from different points of view to make a better insight into the cases from different aspects. The results show that the post-combustion and oxy-fuel CO2 capture systems result in 10.5% and 9.1% decrease in exergy efficiency of the retrofitted plants, respectively, compared with the conventional coal-fired power plant (base case). Additionally, boiler is the major exergy destruction source in all investigated plants. Also, air separation unit and CO2 capture and storage system have the largest amount of exergy destruction among the additional components of retrofitted plant with oxy-fuel combustion and post-combustion CO2 capture systems, respectively.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is the dominant greenhouse gas in terms of the amount of gas emitted and global warming as a consequence of CO2 emissions. As a result, CO2 emission is undoubtedly one of the most challenging environmental problems of our time. Therefore, making large emission reductions will be a major challenge. Various techniques could contribute to emission reductions, including improvements in the efficiency of energy conversion and end use, increased use of renewable and nuclear energy and changes in lifestyle to promote energy conservation and population control. A further technique that has the potential to provide a large contribution to emission reductions is CO2 capture and storage (CCS). CCS is best suited to large point sources of CO2, including power generation, and large energy-consuming industries, such as oil refining and iron, steel, cement and chemical production. This article focuses on power generation, which accounts for more than a third of the 28 G tonne/year of CO2 emitted from fossil fuel use in 2006.1 CCS could contribute to emission reduction from smaller sources, such as transportation and domestic and commercial buildings by increased use of electricity produced in large plants with CCS or by use of hydrogen, which can be co-produced in power plants with CCS. The sequestration of the concentrated CO2 stream is independent of the separation technique and is accomplished using a multistage inter-cooled compressor.1

The three main methods for capturing CO2 in power plants are post-combustion capture, pre-combustion capture and oxy-combustion capture.1 The two most prevalent separation techniques, oxy-fuel combustion and post-combustion separation, are described in the following sections.

sec.title: Oxy-fuel combustion
sec.p: To recover and store CO2 from flue gases of fossil fuel power plants, processes based on oxy-combustion appear to be promising. The concept of the oxy-combustion technology is the combustion with commercially pure oxygen (O2) to achieve high CO2 concentration in the flue gases for the final CO2 separation. The required oxygen is supplied by an air separation unit (ASU) where the nitrogen (N2) is separated from the air. The oxygen-, carbon- and hydrogen-rich combustion environment produces a flue gas stream rich in H2O and CO2, which ideally facilitates a relatively simple CO2 separation process by condensing out the H2O. A great portion of the flue gases has to be recycled to substitute the removed nitrogen and prevent high peak temperatures, thereby reducing material damage and high NOx formation. As oxy-fuel power generation is currently on the pre-demonstration stage of development, many studies dealing with its evaluation are still in progress.2

sec.title: Post-combustion separation
sec.p: Post-combustion separation is accomplished by separating the CO2 from the flue gas stream of an air-fired power plant. There are many mature and widely applied separation technologies that are mainly based on absorption through liquid solvents, adsorption through solid sorbents and separation with membranes. The selection of the technology depends on the flue gas characteristics (temperature, pressure, concentration and volume flow rate); CO2 concentration varies from 5 vol% (dry) for a natural gas combined cycle plant to about 15 vol% (dry) for a pulverized coal fired power plant. In the absorption process, CO2 is captured from the flue gas by a reactive liquid solvent. This technology is widely diffused in chemical process industries and represents the most mature technology now available. The most experienced processes are based on the use of aqueous solutions of alkanolamines, such as monoethanolamine, diethanolamine and methyldiethanolamine.

Before starting the absorbing phase, flue gas is treated in a cooling system and a purifying section (in order to remove particulates and other possible impurities, mainly SOx and NOx, which could cause solvent losses for degradation). Once treated, the flue gas is sent to an absorber tower, in which the CO2 reacts with the aqueous solution of amines, while the cleaned flue gas (essentially hot air) is released in atmosphere; the separation of CO2 is due to a chemical reaction that creates a chemical compound in which CO2 is loosely bound. The CO2-loaded solution is then sent to a stripper section where it is heated, obtaining pure CO2 and regenerating the solvent. While CO2 is dried, compressed and transported in a dense phase to the storage site, the regenerated solvent is newly sent to the absorber tower, after having been cooled down by the CO2-loaded solution exiting the absorber tower in a heat exchanger.
This process can be designed to capture 85–95% of the CO2 in the flue gas, with a >99.9% purity.
The main critical aspect for amine-based processes is represented by the energy consumption needed for regeneration; research activities aim to optimize this issue.

sec.title: Necessity for thermodynamic analysis
sec.p: Thermodynamic analysis based on energy accounts for energy flows in and out of the control volumes within a system, whereas the exergy analysis determines the irreversibilities within the same system. The majority of the causes of thermodynamic imperfection of thermal processes are not accounted for by the energy analysis and it is the exergy analysis that provides significant insights at the design stage. Only exergy analysis accounts the irreversibilities such as heat transfer through a finite temperature difference, chemical reactions, friction, mixing and unrestrained expansion.3 In this regard, exergy analysis of CO2 capture systems could be useful to detect, study and achieve proper integration and, hence, minimization of additional energetic requirements which finally reduce the operational capture cost.4

sec.title: Literature review
sec.p: In open literature, there are a number of researches which deal with the thermodynamic evaluation of the power generation units including CO2 capturing.5–12 As some examples, Simpson and Simon2 compared oxy-fuel combustion and post-combustion on an exergetic basis. They found that the second law efficiency of air separation must reach a critical value before the thermodynamics of oxy-fuel combustion become favorable. Seepana and Jayanti13 proposed a new variant to the oxy-coal combustion in a pulverized coal burner in which CO2-enriched flue gas is used to moderate the flame temperature in conventional oxy-fuel combustion. Thermodynamic exergy analysis of their cycles shows that the optimized CO2-enriched flue gas recycled power plant performs better than retrofitted flue gas recycled system. Lee et al.14 presented an approach for performance evaluation of a commercial-scale coal-fired power plant which was considered for retrofitting with oxy-fuel combustion. Suresh et al.15 analyzed and optimized the air–coal combustion supercritical and ultra supercritical steam power plants using high ash coal. They also studied the effect of oxy-coal combustion on thermodynamic performance of the optimized air–coal combustion power plant. In their study, a significant reduction in plant efficiency was observed for supercritical and ultra supercritical oxy-coal combustion compared with the reference case. Xiong et al.16 performed the exergy analysis of an oxy-combustion pulverized coal fired power plant. According to their results, the exergy efficiency of the oxy-combustion system is 4.08% lower than that of the conventional system.

As mentioned previously, a detailed and comprehensive exergy analysis for a retrofitted conventional coal-fired power plant with oxy-fuel and post-combustion has not been reported to date. Therefore, the objective of this study is to evaluate and quantify the potential of two methods to reduce the energy penalties associated with CO2 separation from a coal-fired power plant. The study involves thermodynamic analysis based on energy and exergy for air–coal combustion (as the base case) and the retrofitted coal-fired power plant with oxy-fuel combustion as well as post-combustion CO2 capture. Also, the exergy efficiencies of the main components of the cycle are calculated and compared with the base case.

sec.title: Exergy analysis
sec.p: Exergy can be divided into four distinct components. The two important ones are the physical exergy and chemical exergy. In this study, the two other components, that is kinetic exergy and potential exergy, are assumed to be negligible as the elevation and speed have negligible changes.17–19 The physical exergy is defined as the maximum theoretical useful work obtained as a system interacted with an equilibrium state.19 The chemical exergy is associated with the departure of the chemical composition of a system from its chemical equilibrium. The chemical exergy is an important part of exergy in a combustion process. In order to do the exergy analysis, mass and energy balances on the system are required to determine the flow rates and energy transfer rates at the control surface. Applying the first and the second laws of thermodynamics, the following exergy balance is obtained continuity equation (1)∑im·i=∑em·e energy equation (2)∑im·ihi+Q·CV=∑em·ehe+W·CV exergy balance equation (3)E·xQ+∑im·iexi=∑em·eexe+E·xW+E·xD where subscripts i and e refer to streams entering and leaving the control volume, respectively. In this equation, ex is the total specific exergy and E·xD the exergy destruction. (4)E·xQ=(1-T0Ti)Q·i (5)E·xW=W· where T is the absolute temperature (K) and subscripts i and 0 refer to environmental conditions, respectively.
The exergy rate of a stream of substance (neglecting the potential and kinetic components) can be written in the form (6)E·x=E·xph+E·xch where (7)E·x=m·ex (8)exph=(h-h0)-T0(S-S0)
The mixture chemical exergy is defined as follows (9)exmixch=[∑i=1nXiexchi+RT0∑i=1nXiLnXi+GE]
The last term, GE, which is the excess free Gibbs energy is negligible at low pressure for a gas mixture.
Fuel-specific exergy can be calculated as (10)exfuel=γf×LHV where γf = 1.06 is the exergy factor based on the lower heating value.17

In the exergy analysis of power plants, the exergy of steam is calculated at all states and the changes in the exergy are determined for each major component. Here, for exergy analysis of the boiler, it has been divided into two parts. The radiant section, in which the main part of heat transfer is done by radiation, and the convective section of the boiler that can be considered as a heat exchanger, in which the heat transfer is considered to be done by convection. The exergy destruction in the heat exchangers, condenser, feedwater heater (FWH) and the convective section of the boiler is due to the large temperature difference between the hot and cold fluids.

In the analysis of the separation units, each unit is considered as a control volume with all its inlet and outlet streams, and heat and work interactions are considered. sec.title: System simulation and operating parameters
sec.p: In the authors’ previous study,21 the conceptual feasibility of retrofitting an air-fired power plant with oxy-fuel combustion was investigated. The existing air-fired power plant was modeled in THERMOFLEX simulation software package and the operating parameters of the cycle were determined. Then, the results of the ASU, which was modeled in ASPENPLUS software, are used for conversion of the simulated model to an oxy-combustion power plant. The resulting composition of flue gas in THERMOFLEX was brought back to the ASPENPLUS and the CO2 compression and sequestration unit was modeled, appropriately.

CO2 absorption cycle was modeled in ASPENPLUS according to the schematic cycle shown in Figure 2. The properties of the flue gas, the steam used in reboiler and cooling water used for CO2 cooling were brought from THERMOFLEX modeling. Also, CO2 compression and sequestration unit was modeled in ASPENPLUS similar to the oxy-fuel CCS unit. Figure 2.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: In this study, the energy and exergy analysis of a retrofitted coal-fired power plant with oxy-fuel combustion and post-combustion was performed and the energy and exergy efficiencies of the cycles were compared with the base case (air-fired power plant). Also, the exergy destruction of each system has been calculated.

Figure 4 shows the exergy destruction of each system for air-fired, oxy-fired and post-combustion, respectively. As it can be seen, in common components (main components of the cycles), the exergy destruction of the oxy-fired power plant is more than the other cases. Figure 4.
Exergy destruction in the main components of the base case and retrofitted plants.
FWH: feedwater heater; ASU: air separation unit; CCS: CO2 capture and storage.

Also, the exergy destruction of the additional equipment (ASU and CCS) is considerable. Comparison between the CCS of the retrofitted plants shows that the exergy destruction of the CCS in post-combustion CO2 capture method is much more than the CCS in oxy-combustion method. Nevertheless, development of solvents with higher operational temperature (increasing absorption temperature) and lower regeneration temperature will reduce the exergetic destruction associated with the heat exchanger which is the most important one in the post-combustion system.4 The exergetic efficiency of CCS in oxy-fuel combustion power plant is high enough; however, new methods such as integration of ASU and CO2 compression with organic Rankine cycle are being developed to reduce the energy and exergy penalties in carbon-capture technologies.22

For oxy-fuel combustion, as it is evident from Figure 4, the exergy destruction in the ASU is considerable. Hence, the effort should be to improve the performance and efficiency of this system and development of new technologies for ASU associated with significantly lower efficiency losses.

Since the boiler has been investigated in two parts (radiant and convectional sections), the exergy destruction of each part has been calculated separately. Figure 5 shows the difference between the exergy destruction in radiant and convectional parts of the boiler in both air-fired and oxy-fired cases. For all cases, the major part of the exergy destruction is placed in the radiant section of the boiler, in which two highly irreversible processes, combustion and mixing, occur. Also, due to the high irreversibility of heat transfer across a finite temperature difference, the convective section of the boiler has a considerable amount of exergy destruction among the plant components. This means that the boiler should be improved from exergy efficiency point of view. Figure 5.
Exergy destruction in boiler sections of the base case and retrofitted plants.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this study, energy and exergy analysis of a retrofitted air-fired power plant with two CO2 capture technologies, oxy-fuel combustion and post-combustion, was performed. The study covered the systems for air separation, firing, boiler operation and CO2 separation and compression. The exergy destruction of each component was determined and the results were compared with the base case.

Among the plant equipment, boiler has the largest exergy destruction which is out of the capture system. This means that boiler system still needs to be improved in terms of the second law, and, as a result, efforts at improving the performance of the common components of the power plants should be directed at improving the boiler performance, since it will lead to the largest improvement to the plant’s efficiency. The results of exergy analysis for the boilers show that the furnace (boiler radiant section) has the largest exergy destruction among the plant components in all the cases. The exergy efficiency of the radiant section in an oxy-fuel plant is 3.2% more than that in the base case and post-combustion CO2 capture plant. For each boiler model, the exergy efficiency in the convectional section of the boiler in an oxy-combustion plant is 1.5% more than that in the other two cases studied.

In addition, the exergy destruction in the other common components, i.e. turbines, condensers and FWHs, is more considerable in oxy-fuel combustion plant in comparison with the other cases. The exergy destruction in these components in the case of post-combustion CO2 capture with absorbing system is less than the other cases due to the extracted steam from cross over to supply CCS thermal energy input which leads to less steam passes through the steam turbine and condenser.

Besides, ASU and CCS are the major sources of exergy destruction in retrofitted plants, on which the improvement should be focused. The ASU in the retrofitted plant with oxy-fuel combustion has very low exergy efficiency (32.19%), but the exergy efficiency of the CCS in this case is much higher (83.4%). In the power plant including post-combustion CO2 capture, CCS has less exergetic efficiency than that in an oxy-fuel plant, as it contains the distillation process.

Furthermore, the results show a significant reduction in plant energy and exergy efficiency after retrofitting, in comparison with the base case. In contrast with conventional air-firing mode, in oxy-fuel mode, net power, net electric efficiency and the exergy efficiency have decreased 15%, 9.7% and 9.1%, respectively, which is due to power consumption in ASU and carbon sequestration unit. Also, net power, net electric efficiency and the exergy efficiency have decreased 15%, 9.7% and 9.1%, consequently in the post-combustion CO2 capture, which is due to the energy consumption in reboiler which is supplied by the steam from power generation unit and energy consumption in the sequestration and compression unit. The net power loss per 1 kg/s of CO2 captured in retrofitted plant with post-combustion CO2 capture system is approximately 30% more than that in the oxy-fuel plant due to the large amount of steam required for CCS plant, which shows that the oxy-fuel plant is relatively more advantageous than the post-combustion CO2 capture with absorbing system from the energy point of view.
